06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:24): Emon: what are you doing again? and what are you looking for?
53dfa9c26414d8249c2da511a5932909 (02:24): emon, i used ado and dao etc years ago
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:24): the only thing I'm looking for right now is a good binary diff/patch util for C#
53dfa9c26414d8249c2da511a5932909 (02:24): but its not what it used to be..
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:24): main2: what are you doing again? and what are you looking for?
53dfa9c26414d8249c2da511a5932909 (02:25): nowadays, i only work with sql..
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:25): I might just port bsdiff, but it's a nightmare of bad C syntax and deprecated IO
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:25): my conversion rate will probably be like four lines per day :P
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:25): Emon: if a utility can diff and patch binaries, it should theoretically work for any binary, even C# ones
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:26): GoatCheez, I said a GOOD one :P
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:27): I would very much like to write my own util
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:27): since it needs to do some autoupdating stuff
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:27): Emon: use a basic diff algo then... it should be failry straight forward
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:28): bsdiff makes patches some 15% smaller than rtpatch
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:28): lol, convert that prog to C# and binary files
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:28): my project doesnt need unified diff :P
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (02:29): your update tool will be a binary diff?

0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:29): the guy who wrote it describes an algorithm in his thesis that produces patches even 20% smaller than THAT, but I'm betting my head would implode if I tried to comprehend the math
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:29): just zip the patches, they should contain pretty redundant data
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:30): hell, make them XML based, they'll still zip down to the same amount
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:30): that would just mean another person is using XML just because it's there
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:30): on the other hand it might be fun to port bsdiff since it would be significantly better
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (02:30): GoatCheez: sounds like SOAP to me
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:30): it'd mean they could be easily read by other programs
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:30): er, not xml, I mean just a simple diff + zip or something
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (02:30): AnarkiNet: yeah, and it'd be fundamentally stupid
69e2e9b6faa43ce63a2ecee941ecc641 (02:31): what the hell do you do with the packet? a large sequence of writes?
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:31): yeah, use XML for your diffs, because we all know that all diffs are stored in an xml format lol
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:31): each byte would be an attribute
0194bfef36fc3ad600f7beb9ee198871 (02:31): where's the fun if your patches aren't 500 times the size they should be
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:32): why not MIME encode the binary files,
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:32): even if they were 500 times bigger, XML is so extrordinarily redundant that it'll still compress down a huge amount
11fcd5cb44b5fee3cc0ae7f2d1a6a238 (02:32): if you use something like WinRK or PAQAR you can get like 95%+ text compression
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:32): yes, but the XML would still be totally useless
405830ce0e351e7acb00317f406b772f (02:32): i don't think you're allowed to say bad things about xml
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:33): I'll fire ya in a heartbeat if i hear ya badmouth xml!
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:39): so anyone have any idea about making sure a code segment is run with the application that is executing it the foremost window with focus(activated)?
06d9f5004faf7205aca782823f1c53be (02:42): i have a code segment.... i want to make sure that the application is the foremost window when that sement runs
